title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [2–4 may 1860]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [2–4 May 1860]
text: Brooklyn – 3 May 1860Dear Walteri have got all your letters and life of john brown and all the money and comes real good I can tell you i just about get dreaned and that fechesfetches me quite right again we thought you would be through this week and should begin to look for you home but your letter says you are not) we are all pretty well I am well i had A pery bad cold and coughfcough when Jeffy wrote and had been cleaning house and worked very hard but i am well now Eddy is some lame yet he cantcan't doodo much I think itsit's the rheumattis Andrew has got quite well he has been here three days in sucsessionsuccession he and jim I llI'll tell you walt all about family affairs and then I llI'll touch on not the fight nor politickspolitics) well we scrachscratch along the same as usual I paid the rent the month of aprilApril the 5 you sent me and what Georg vannostrand paid me but i am in debt to ammerman about 10 dollardollars not lately but when mary was here I had to get so many things if that was paid I would feel releivedrelieved but I cantcan't see any way at present so we ll hope for the best we like the people that has taken the house very well A man and wife and one son 17 and one 9 years all but the 9 year one belongs to mr beachersbeechers church she is a long island woman and very clever they have the back bacementbasement and the next flourfloor through and one bedroom in the attic for 14 dollars per month we are a little cramptcramped in the basement we miss the water but we llwe 'll do the best we can they want gassgas very much but I did not promicepromise it when they hired) George vannostrand paid me one night and left next morning without any ceremony we expected him again left his things here but he has not been) Fred and bob coopper was here last sundaySunday staidstayed till toward evening) and Hector TindaleTyndale was here last week he looks very fat and well and behaved very friendly indeed talked much of his mother says she died of gout in the stomach she was not at his house but at her daughters he said he was from home the Doctor said there was no danger when he went she died before his return he thought you had forgotten him or you would have sent him a few lines my pen is so badgood bie Walt Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [2–4 May 1860]
